On the 14th of April, the prisoner and another woman came into the shop about 3 o'clock, and offered an apron in pawn for 1 s. the prisoner presented it, I advanced 9 d. on it: they went away, and in a few minutes the prisoner returned alone, and took out of her apron a petticoat, which she put on the counter, and then seeing the shop ticket on it, drew it back; I saw her fumbling down with it, which gave me suspicion. She immediately took the cotton out of her apron and offered that; when she put it on the counter, she saw the ticket on that Mr. Hulme laid hold of it, and she pulled to get it from him, he got it from her and kept it. We examined the ticket and saw it was Brooks's, and sent to him: he claimed it and the petticoat. I have had it ever since.

JOHN BROOKS
. The ticket is mine and was in the cotton.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN TAYLOR
. I am one of the beadles of St. George's, Bloomsbury. I was sent for, and took charge of her; I found 15 duplicates on her - none of them have been claimed.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to pawn an apron; the otherwoman pushed something off the guard and gave it me; when I came out I went to pawn them.
GUILTY . Aged 52.
Transported for life .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

694.
JAMES HIPP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of March , 17 s. 6 d. the property of
William Mansfield
.

WILLIAM MANSFIELD
. I live in Union-street, Shadwell
. The prisoner was a stranger to me. On Shrove Tuesday I was employed by Mr. Elliot, a wine merchant, to take some wine. I sent the prisoner to Poplar with some goods. He was to have 17 s. back. He brought it and delivered it to my wife. I never saw the money. My wife is not here.
NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

695.
JOSEPH BOLTON
was indicted for
stealing on the 6th of June, 1819 , twelve pounds of lead, value 2 s. and ten pounds of copper, value 12 s. the goods of
Thomas Richardson
, (since deceased), and fixed to a building of his .

JAMES SALTER
. I am a gardener, at Fulham. I knew Mr.
Thomas Richardson
when he was alive. This lead was on the outside of the privy, - the copper joined it, and covered an other building. I was called up about twelve in the night of the 5th of June, 1819, to go to market, and I saw two persons drop from Mr. Richardson's back wall. I went after
James Dormas
whom I took, - he was tried and convicted. The other I did not know. The prisoner lived in the neighbourhood about a fortnight after the robbery, and then left.

SARAH ROWLAND
. I was servant to Mr. Richardson, he has been dead two years on the 5th of July; he was alive at the time of the robbery, his name was Thomas. Some part of the privy was robbed before. After Dormas was taken, I found it completely stripped.

JAMES SHARP
. I drive Salter's horse. I was up on that morning, and saw the two men come over the wall. I cannot say the prisoner was one.
R. ELLINGHAM. I apprehended the prisoner, and we told him the charges. He said he was willing to go with me.
NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

696.
JOHN WELLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of March , one saddle, value 2 s.; one halter, value 6 d.; and one bridle value 2 s. ; the goods of
Samuel Dalton
,
Barnaby Sanders
, and
William Wood
.

SAMUEL DALTON
. I am a cornchandler .
Barnaby Sanders
and
William Wood
are joint executors with me to the estate of
Eliza Dalton
. The property was in a stable in Pratt's Mews, Camden-town
.

WILLIAM HALES
. I keep a horse and cart. About five or six weeks ago the prisoner worked for me, - we were out selling sand, - he asked if I wanted to buy a saddle and halter, as he knew a person who had one to sell. I said, I do not want them, - he afterwards said they were very good, - I said I would look at them on Sunday. I saw them in the stable. I do not know who put them there. When I saw him, I said I was informed he had been and got 4 s. from my wife. He now denied selling them to my wife. I told him I should have nothing to do with them, and to bring the young man, or I would kick him and the harness out together. He absconded.
Cross-examined by MR. HONE. Q. What trade are you? - A. I carry out sand and bricks.

ELIZA HALES
. I am the wife of the last witness. I never saw the harness. The prisoner brought me some money his master had sent him for, and he said,
"Mistress you are to give me 4 s. 6 d.; I am going to buy a saddle and halter for 4 s." I did not like to give him the money, but I did.

REBECCA PRICE
. I was with Mrs. Hales, and heard the prisoner ask for 4 s. to buy a saddle and halter; she gave it to him at last. I never saw the things.

JOHN DAVIS
. I am a Bow-street patrole. I apprehended the prisoner last Friday. I told him what I took him for, he said he was not the only one to blame, and said Hales sent him for it.
NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury before Mr. Common Sergeant.

697.
THOMAS GUNTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of February , one handkerchief, value 3 s., the property of Sir
Hugh Dalrymple
, from his person .
The Prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.
